qas.question: What has crime rate been show to be correlated with in a society?
What is almost identical across all nations and jurisdictions?
Over how many studies have shown that violence is more common in societies with income differences?
How much of a difference in homicide rates are related to inequality?
What is it estimated that about half of all variation in homicide rates can be accounted for by?

answers.text: differences in the amount of inequality
differences in the amount of inequality

qas.question: What has crime rate been shown not to be correlated with in a society?
What is never identical across all nations and jurisdictions?
Over how many studies have shown that violence is less common in societies with income differences?
How much of a difference in homicide rates aren't related to inequality?

plausible_answers.text: differences in the amount of inequality

qas.question: What is it estimated that about a third of all variation in homicide rates can be accounted for by?

context: Crime rate has also been shown to be correlated with inequality in society. Most studies looking into the relationship have concentrated on homicides – since homicides are almost identically defined across all nations and jurisdictions. There have been over fifty studies showing tendencies for violence to be more common in societies where income differences are larger. Research has been conducted comparing developed countries with undeveloped countries, as well as studying areas within countries. Daly et al. 2001 found that among U.S States and Canadian Provinces there is a tenfold difference in homicide rates related to inequality. They estimated that about half of all variation in homicide rates can be accounted for by differences in the amount of inequality in each province or state. Fajnzylber et al. (2002) found a similar relationship worldwide. Among comments in academic literature on the relationship between homicides and inequality are:
